title: Conference v2.0: An Uncertain Version of the OAEI Conference Benchmark
segmentation: So this is work that I did with my PhD advisor Pascal Hitzler from my dissertation.
This isn't exactly a new benchmark, instead it's more of a different version of the existing OAI conference benchmark.

So here's my 22nd introduction to ontology alignment, though I'm sure everybody knows this, but the point I want to make is that when we specify a match or a relationship between two ontologies, we typically are going to have the entity from the first ontology, the entity from the second ontology, the relationship that we think holds between these two entities, and the confidence or certainty value that we have in that match.
So it's this last part, the certainty value that I'm going to focus on in this talk.
OK, so we're going to go for a little bit of audience participation here.
Please raise your hand if you or anyone in your research group has been working in ontology alignment.
OK, now Please wait, keep your hands up guys.
OK now please put your hand down if you've used the OAI conference track to evaluate your work in ontology alignment.
OK, so my point is that this is an extremely influential benchmark right?
I nearly everybody who's working in the field has used this benchmark to evaluate their their systems.

And the reason why is because it's it's very long running, so it's established in 2005 and a lot of effort went into establishing this benchmark and it was primarily developed by three people, but each year for the first several years of the benchmarks existence they would get together at consensus workshops in the ontology matching workshop to kind of debate any of the mappings that should or should not have been included and discuss how to resolve any inconsistencies.
One of the things that to note about this benchmark, though, is that the confidence values of all of the matches in the reference alignment.
They're all 1.0, so they're all perfectly confident.
OK, and then they've tried really hard putting a lot of manual effort to try to get logical consistency, although I guess they don't quite have complete consistency.
OK, so this benchmark has done a lot of good work in improving the performance of ontology alignment systems over the last decade.
The performance of both the best performing system in the median system has increased over that time.
But like I said, I was concerned with the the idea of the the perfect confidence in all of the matches.
I didn't think that that really reflected the opinion of people when they when they approach this alignment.
So what I did was I asked a group of experts to opine on on the matches in this reference alignment.
So initially I took the 15 best performing alignment systems from 2013 along with all the things matches in the reference alignments.
I took all the matches.
The systems created the whole group of them and tried getting people to opine on all of those matches.
There was 768 matches and they very politely told me to go jump in a Lake.
So instead I had to kind of narrow down my set.
So what I did was I just looked at things that are already in the reference alignment and any matches in the reference alignment that all of the 15 best performing systems from last year got right.
I considered those trivial, so I didn't bother asking about those.
So 309 matches in the reference alignment 140.
One of those were trivial, and by all of the trivial matches happen to be exact string equivalences.
That leaves 168 that I needed to ask by my group of experts about when you ask people if if two things are equivalent from different ontologies, you can't just ask them.
You know.
Does a mean the same thing as be?
You need to give them some kind of context to work with so that they can see how these labels are used in the different ontologies.

So I took all of the axioms from each ontology that was that were that involve the entities that I was asking about an I fed those axioms through open universities Al to English, kind of translator, and that's what I displayed to my users.
So I got results from.
I got answers from 13 people.
Out of the 168 so yeah, at 168 nontrivial matches they agreed.
Like if the experts as a group, the majority of them agreed with 168 of those matches and they disagreed with 60 two of them.
If we looked at this group of 13 experts as kind of an alignment system, and if it had competed in the 2013, OH AEI, it's F measure would have been .89, and the performance of the best.
Visual expert was .95 and the worst individual expert was .78.
This is kind of a tier above the performance of automated alignment systems from last year.
The other thing that I want to note is the amount of discord in the responses.
So of my 13 experts, they all had the same answer either yes or no on only nine of the 168 matches and they were completely split seven to six on 40 matches.
So it was really hard for them to.
To get consensus on matches.

Of these nine that they all agreed on, they all happen to be yes, and six of those nines happened to be exact lexical equivalences that were missed by one of the alignment systems last year for some reason.

The other thing that I want to note is that people just seem to like you know those inkblot tests where people will see something in the inkblot, even though it's completely random, people seem to approach a pining on these matches in a similar kind of way where for whatever reason they tend to see relationships even when they are tenuous at best.

OK, so now I'm going to switch gears a little bit an instead of looking at the current version of the conference test set with the 1.0 confidences as the reference or gold standard, I'm going to look at the version produced by these experts as that reference with the confidence measure set to the percentage of the experts that agreed on each of the matches.
And then I'm going to evaluate the systems that competed in last year's OAI.
According to this version.
So there's two different ways that we can do that now that we have continuous confidence values.

We can evaluate it discretely, which are in a discrete manner, which kind of corresponds to what's currently done, and in this sense, if the reference alignment has a confidence value of .6 and alignment system.
You know has a confidence value, let's say 5.4.
We're going to count that as completely wrong, but if it was .5 we would count that as completely correct.
Um, or it's the exact threshold used here doesn't really matter that the general idea is that it's discrete.
It's kind of an all or nothing thing, and then we can evaluate it also continuously.

So the idea is that sorry, the idea is that intuitively, if an alignment system misses a match that the experts had .9% point 9 confidence in that should be, you know, worse to miss that match then to miss one that they only had .51% confidence in.
So we can have a metric that takes that into consideration, and this is described more in the paper.
I think this is very helpful for evaluating alignment systems because it eliminates the need to find a threshold like the best performing threshold.
To evaluate this systems against.
And when you do this, I mean this threshold is kind of placing a discrete limit on something that's inherently continuous, so I would say that's going to.
It's good to avoid that.
OK, so if we evaluate this system from last year according to this version of the conference thing conference benchmark, they the average F measure increases by 10%.

There's not a lot of difference in evaluate in the discrete versus continuous performance of these systems, and that's because most current alignment systems generate confidence values that are really clustered on the high end of the spectrum.
So like from .9 to 1.0, and that's all the confidence values that they're generating.
Think if this were stressed more as a means of evaluating systems, we might see them developing ways to produce confidence values that more.
Closely correlated with human opinion.
OK, so it took a lot of prodding to get my 13 experts to opine on the reference alignments and to be honest, I think Pascal is my advisor.
Prodding them was what actually helped, so I looked at can we crowd source these confidence values?
And how well will those agree with with the experts?
So I used Amazon's Mechanical Turk.
I did this over Easter weekend, got my results in two days and spent $135.
I displayed these these same exact questions to the Mechanical Turk people that I displayed to the experts.

So if we look at again, if we take the performance of the Mechanical Turk people and consider them in alignment system on the current version of the conference reference alignments, they would have an F measure of .90.
And if you ever called the expert F measure was .89, so this is really similar performance.
If we evaluate them against the discrete version of the expert generated alignment that measures .88.
If we use a continuous version, it's .9 Seven.
So the reason for this discrepancy is on the hardest of questions where there was the most discord.
That was where Mechanical Turk in the experts disagreed the most, but the confidence the percentage of Turkers match very well with the percentage of experts that that agreed on these matches.
And then finally this.
This could be argued.

This is a little bit misleading because these results include the 141 trivial matches and just assumed that everybody would always get those right if we leave those out and evaluate, we get an F measure of .91.
So the bottom line is I think this is a very reasonable approach to generating confidence values like crowdsourcing versus asking experts.
Most alignment systems right now tend to focus on finding one to one equivalences.

If we're going to move towards finding different types of relationships, I think that we're going to need more and more benchmarks, so I think this crowdsourcing approach to becoming more popular in the field, and I think that it's it's definitely a viable way.
Forward.
But there are some downsides, right?
One of them I mentioned before.
People kind of naturally see things that maybe aren't there.
The other one is a logical consistency's are likely, and I don't think this can be avoided.

There's no way that you can give people enough contextual information to avoid logical inconsistencies in your reference alignments, but maybe we can talk to the like, take the alignment we get this way and talk to Danielle and Alessandro and kind of work with it that way.
Some work on using crowd sources for crowdsourcing for biomedical ontologies, and that's actually work fairly well, but it's possible that for some domains or some really complex ontologies this.
This might cause problems.
Alright, that's all I've got.
I wanted to ask you the did you use the air A1 reference alignment or the private One array 2?
Because let's say I've never had to look at the differences, but I know that there exists a private one.
OK, so.

Just in case you guys don't know the the RA one versus RA 2 conference benchmarks, they made a slight modification in 2011 where they kind of completed all the implications of the existing reference alignments and then removed any inconsistencies that were generated.
I used to everyone in this.
It's what I had all the yeah.
OK, thanks.
I must say that I think that maybe because you you stare at one, so then it's incoherent, maybe, but we can maybe talk about how to improve this this aspect, but I wanted to say something else.
I was already inspecting your you reference alignment and I was really surprised that a lot of confidence values were very loud and I would expect them more higher.
So then I realized that the difference in approaches for the construction of reference alignment that we took.
Our case, we think that we try to reach consensus among.
Yes, that's true that among just only three are reviewers or evaluators, and we were discussing about each each correspondence so very accurately.
And in your case, if I understood well you, you compute degree of agreement between among the experts.
And so I think that maybe if you if you enable discussion between this expert, so maybe the confidence very values will be would be higher and almost like 1.0.

So my question is that you consider to enable discussion in future work on the second point is that I would be happy if you could include your reference alignment into the conference track, so thanks.
And thanks, so I really want to thank you for organizing the contract conference track.
It's amazingly good and helpful for the community.
I think in terms of having people interact, I'm trying to come up with the.
I think the term is game with a purpose for this kind of thing.
The current ones I have are rather boring though, so I'm working in that direction on that, but it may be worthwhile just to facilitate direct communication on this task.
So yeah, that's definitely something I could look at.
Did you do any spam analysis?
Yeah, so I did so there is.
There can be a lot of problem with spam on Mechanical Turk.
So I I looked at, had some Golden questions where they were very obviously the answer was very obviously yes or no.
An looked at performance on the Golden questions versus performance as a as a whole like agreement with the entire group of people to try to detect spammers.
I only ran into two spammers out of my.
The most of the people that started on this task did all of the tasks all the way through because I paid them well and it was really kind of straightforward.

I only ran into two people who are spammers, but I think that the reason that happened was because before I started this experiment, I got advice on a Mechanical Turk forum and then the lady who gave me advice got all of her friends to answer all my questions so they were really high quality users.
For what it's worth, I have done some other.
I'm trying to develop a reference alignment for the properties between DB Pedia and Jago, and for that I was asking people are they equivalent?

Are they sub in super relationship or is there some other relationship or is there no relationship and what I found is that when you ask people these more complex questions I don't know if it's spammers or they're just not as good at it but the performance seems to have suffered from that.
So if you.
Followell auroras approach.
We could say that the we should not aim always for high agreement, but sometimes having information that there is low agreement also is very worthwhile right?
So it can say something about the quality of the of the mappings.
Is there a way that we can learn how to predict which mappings will be low agreement?
Where do they round coming from that knowing that there's low agreement predicts the performance of the different alignment systems as a really interesting question?
Well, to be honest, I hadn't thought of that at all, but I think that that's very interesting and I will be thinking about it a lot in the future, right?
I mean, right now the the best predictor of agreements on classes is string similarity among the classes, right?
The best predictor of agreement among properties is.
Having string similarity of the property name but also the domain and range of the property, these seem to be what the people are focusing on, But yeah, that would be very interesting.
They could try to quantify that.
Final question.
Thank you.
